title: 5 Of The Weirdest Ways People Are Using AI Tools In 2025
description: The use cases for Artificial Intelligence can expand far beyond one's imagination. These are five of the weirdest ways AI tools are used in 2025.
content: AI is showing up in the strangest of places. People use it for seemingly everything, from asking embarrassing questions to building entire businesses. They're using it to create content, get help with homework, brainstorm ideas, and understand comple... [5468 chars]

title: CT scan changes over one year predict outcomes in fibrotic lung disease
description: Researchers at National Jewish Health have shown that subtle increases in lung scarring, detected by an artificial intelligence-based tool on CT scans taken one year apart, are associated with disease progression and survival in patients with fibrotic interstitial lung disease. The findings, recently published in the American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, suggest that computer-based image analysis may provide an earlier, more objective way to identify patients at highest risk for worsening disease.

title: How does Singapore detect potholes on roads? With AI
description: Artificial intelligence is being used to detect potholes and other road defects in Singapore with over 90 per cent accuracy.
content:
SINGAPORE: Artificial intelligence and video analytics are increasingly being deployed to keep Singapore’s roads free of defects such as potholes, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) said.

title: Goldman CEO Predicts AI May Increase Staff Size Over the Next Decade

title: Nvidia Competitor Cerebras Shelves IPO Plans Days After Touching $8 Billion Valuation
description: Artificial intelligence chipmaker Cerebras Systems scrapped plans for an IPO on Friday, days after the Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ: NVDA) competitor announced a fresh fundraising round that sent its valuation up to $8 billion.

title: The Inference | AI Enters The Gym, Inside India’s Consumer AI Paradox, And More
description: Artificial intelligence is no longer just about breakthroughs in labs or pumping billions of dollars into data centres — it’s in our hospitals, courtrooms, classrooms, and on the battlefield.
